nodes.bodyText: Add the provider and channel descriptor information back into the about model like we used to in older versions of Alert.
Note this DescriptorMetadata has no operations data contained in it.  So the UI will not display anything based on permissions if these DescriptorMetadata objects are used.
Possibly a future improvement but should we create a getDescriptors() method in DescriptorMetadataActions that only takes in a DescriptorType name?
Implemented your suggestion because the getDescriptorsByType is what we currently do for the about page.
This class contains the contents of the DescriptorController.  This provides methods to create the descriptor metadata to be used in both the about page and the user based descriptor data.
Create all DescriptorMetadata objects regardless of user permission.  This is used by the AboutReader.
This is the method the DescriptorController uses.  Gets the DescriptorMetadata based on the user's permissions.  This is the same type of code that the controller executed in the past.
Create the metadata for all descriptors with UI Components.

Create the DescriptorMetadata based on the user permissions.  Refactored the code from the controller because we were making an extra method call that we didn't need.  Check the permissions here.  If the user has permissions then create the DescriptorMetadata objects.
Removed code from this class and moved it into DescriptorMetadataActions

This is a bug that might need to be patched in older versions.  The cache doesn't get updated when a new role is created.  Therefore this descriptor list for the user in the UI would be empty causing the original issue.

For each descriptor (providers or channels) check the users list of descriptors and see if they have permission for a Global UI context.  If they do then navigate will be true and the item in the table will be a link not just the name of the descriptor.

I like this.
A comment for the sake of other reviewers who may not be comfortable with this:

I think metadata should be available to any authenticated user, but the UI should be responsible for determining what metadata it displays. Only the field_values table contains sensitive content that we care about securing. As an open source project, all of this metadata is available here on GitHub anyway, so why complicate our API by trying to restrict it on a per-user basis.
